title: Walter Dean
text:
Walter Kevin Dean (born June 1, 1968) is an American former <a href="American%20football">football</a> <a href="running%20back">running back</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for the at <a href="Grambling%20State%20University">Grambling State University</a>. In his senior year, he led the nation in <a href="rush%20%28American%20football%29">rushing</a> and won the 1990 <a href="Walter%20Payton%20Award">Walter Payton Award</a> as the most outstanding player in <a href="Division%20I-AA">Division I-AA</a> football. He played professional football for one season in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) after he was selected by the <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a> in the sixth round of the <a href="1991%20NFL%20Draft">1991 NFL Draft</a>.
Early life.
Dean was born on June 1, 1968, in <a href="Ruston%2C%20Louisiana">Ruston, Louisiana</a>, to Walter, a concrete company dispatcher, and Betty Dean, an administrative secretary at <a href="Grambling%20State%20University">Grambling State University</a>. He also has a younger brother who played soccer, Keith, who was one of Louisiana's leading <a href="high%20school%20football">interscholastic</a> players, and with whom he shared a bunk-bed according to their mother. Walter Dean attended <a href="Grambling%20State%20University%20Laboratory%20High%20School">Grambling State University Laboratory High School</a> in <a href="Grambling%2C%20Louisiana">Grambling, Louisiana</a> and turned down <a href="athletic%20scholarship">offers</a> from major college football programs such as <a href="Nebraska%20Cornhuskers%20football">Nebraska</a> and <a href="LSU%20Tigers%20football">Louisiana State</a> in order to attend Grambling State. Dean said, "I wanted to go to a college where everybody I knew wouldn't have to sign up for a <a href="frequent-flyer%20program">frequent-flyer program</a> in order to see me play."
College career.
At Grambling, Dean studied <a href="business%20management">business management</a> and played football for the <a href="Grambling%20State%20Tigers%20football">Grambling State Tigers</a> as a <a href="running%20back">running back</a>. He earned the nickname "<a href="American%20Express">American Express</a>" due to the belief of his coach, <a href="Eddie%20Robinson%20%28football%20coach%29">Eddie Robinson</a>, that the team should 'never leave home without him', a saying similar to the slogan of the eponymous credit card company. "<a href="Sports%20Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a>" called Dean possibly the "best runner produced by a predominantly black college since <a href="Walter%20Payton">Walter Payton</a> came out of <a href="Jackson%20State%20University">Jackson State</a> in 1975." Former Grambling and <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Rams">Los Angeles Rams</a> <a href="fullback%20%28American%20football%29">fullback</a> <a href="Paul%20%26quot%3BTank%26quot%3B%20Younger">Paul "Tank" Younger</a> said about Dean, "You take one look at him and you think, hey, he doesn't look that tough. He isn't the huge, muscle-flexing type of back, but once you see him run the ball, you want to check out his scrapbook."
At Grambling, Dean recorded a career total of 3,328 yards and 41 touchdowns. As a junior in 1989, Dean scored 18 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s and set a school <a href="rush%20%28American%20football%29">rushing</a> record when he compiled 1,269 yards. In 1990, Dean recorded 17 touchdowns and the Division I-AA season-best 1,401 rushing yards. Against , he recorded 137 yards on just 15 carries (9.13 average). Against <a href="Hampton%20Pirates">Hampton</a>, he compiled a career-high 232 yards and helped lead the Tigers to a 22-3 victory. Grambling finished the season with an 8–3 record, including a win against their arch-rival, , in the <a href="Bayou%20Classic">Bayou Classic</a>.
Eddie Robinson believed that Dean was deserving of the <a href="Heisman%20Trophy">Heisman Trophy</a>, awarded annually to the best college football player, but acknowledged that voters would not seriously consider a Division I-AA player for the honor. Dean did, however, win the <a href="Walter%20Payton%20Award">Walter Payton Award</a>, which is the award bestowed annually upon Division I-AA football's most outstanding player.
Professional football.
Dean was selected in the sixth round of the <a href="1991%20NFL%20Draft">1991 NFL Draft</a> by the <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a> (149th pick overall). He then played <a href="1991%20Green%20Bay%20Packers%20season">one season</a> for Green Bay. In 1991, he saw action in nine games and recorded one <a href="kick%20return">kick return</a> and one <a href="fumble">fumble</a>.
